<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 215, 356, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 195, 907, 210]]<|/det|>
9709/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 217, 907, 232]]<|/det|>
May/June 2012  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 239, 907, 253]]<|/det|>
1 hour 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 322, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 352, 828, 368]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 327, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 462, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 509, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 82, 645, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the region enclosed by the curve \(y = \frac{6}{2x - 3}\), the \(x\)-axis and the lines \(x = 2\) and \(x = 3\). Find, in terms of \(\pi\), the volume obtained when this region is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(x\)-axis. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 402, 97, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 453, 428]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = 4\sqrt{x} + \frac{2}{\sqrt{x}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 448, 154, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 447, 390, 476]]<|/det|>
Obtain an expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 450, 917, 469]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 485, 153, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 485, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
A point is moving along the curve in such a way that the \(x\)-coordinate is increasing at a constant rate of 0.12 units per second. Find the rate of change of the \(y\)-coordinate when \(x = 4\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 549, 94, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 548, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
The coefficient of \(x^{3}\) in the expansion of \((a + x)^{5} + (2 - x)^{6}\) is 90. Find the value of the positive constant \(a\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 610, 94, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) has coordinates \((-1, -5)\) and the point \(B\) has coordinates (7, 1). The perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) meets the \(x\)-axis at \(C\) and the \(y\)-axis at \(D\). Calculate the length of \(CD\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 677, 94, 696]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 673, 151, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 672, 520, 702]]<|/det|>
Prove the identity \(\tan x + \frac{1}{\tan x} \equiv \frac{1}{\sin x \cos x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 676, 917, 695]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 718, 151, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 715, 645, 746]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\frac{2}{\sin x \cos x} = 1 + 3 \tan x\), for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 720, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 82, 678, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a metal plate made by removing a segment from a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(8\mathrm{~cm}\). The line \(AB\) is a chord of the circle and angle \(AOB = 2.4\) radians. Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 300, 153, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 300, 299, 318]]<|/det|>
the length of \(AB\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 300, 920, 318]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 324, 151, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 324, 366, 343]]<|/det|>
the perimeter of the plate,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 325, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 349, 136, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 349, 322, 368]]<|/det|>
the area of the plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 395, 96, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 826, 415]]<|/det|>
(a) In an arithmetic progression, the sum of the first \(n\) terms, denoted by \(S_{n}\), is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 421, 554, 443]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = n^{2} + 8n.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 531, 469]]<|/det|>
Find the first term and the common difference.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 451, 920, 469]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 480, 146, 499]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 480, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
In a geometric progression, the second term is 9 less than the first term. The sum of the second and third terms is 30. Given that all the terms of the progression are positive, find the first term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 559, 94, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 559, 153, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 559, 633, 579]]<|/det|>
Find the angle between the vectors \(3\mathbf{i} - 4\mathbf{k}\) and \(2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} - 6\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 590, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
The vector \(\overrightarrow{OA}\) has a magnitude of 15 units and is in the same direction as the vector \(3\mathbf{i} - 4\mathbf{k}\). The vector \(\overrightarrow{OB}\) has a magnitude of 14 units and is in the same direction as the vector \(2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} - 6\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 645, 151, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 495, 664]]<|/det|>
Express \(\overrightarrow{OA}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 645, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 151, 699]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 680, 500, 699]]<|/det|>
Find the unit vector in the direction of \(\overrightarrow{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 699]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 83, 725, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 364, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = - x^{2} + 8x - 10\) which passes through the points \(A\) and \(B\). The curve has a maximum point at \(A\) and the gradient of the line \(BA\) is 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 412, 154, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 412, 420, 429]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 443, 154, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 645, 470]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int y \mathrm{d}x\) and hence evaluate the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 501, 104, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 378, 518]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 523, 581, 580]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}:x\mapsto 2x + 5\qquad \mathrm{for} x\in \mathbb{R},\] \[\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto \frac{8}{x - 3}\qquad \mathrm{for} x\in \mathbb{R}, x\neq 3.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 599, 154, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 599, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
Obtain expressions, in terms of \(x\), for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) and \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\), stating the value of \(x\) for which \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\) is not defined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 616, 920, 634]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 647, 151, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 645, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) on the same diagram, making clear the relationship between the two graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 692, 153, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 692, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Given that the equation \(\mathrm{fg}(x) = 5 - kx\), where \(k\) is a constant, has no solutions, find the set of possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 707, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
